items.title: Syrian Refugees Strain Resources in Jordan
items.abstract: Despite plans by aid organizations to help at least 50,000 urban refugees, a large number will be left out because of the rising numbers of Syrians fleeing across the border each day.
keywords: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )

items.title: Together a Century, City and Oil Giant Hit a Rough Patch
items.abstract: Chevron has spent millions in recent years trying to shore up its relationship with Richmond, Calif., but many residents still oppose the company’s efforts to repair a refinery hit by a fire.

items.title: Nashville’s Latest Big Hit Could Be the City Itself
items.abstract: The city, which sat on the sidelines while its Southern sisters boomed, has found itself in the national spotlight, with economic gains and a newly found popularity.

items.title: Applause Is Muted in City With Role in President’s Rise
items.abstract: In Springfield, Ill., the state capital where President Obama served as a legislator, residents looked to his second term with a mixture of anxiety, uncertainty and a muted hopefulness.

items.title: Two Cities in One
items.abstract: Do you live in Washington or in D.C.?

items.title: The New York City ID Card
items.abstract: The president of Amalgamated Bank writes that banks need to get on board with New York City’s program.

items.title: ‘The Geography of Genius,’ by Eric Weiner
items.abstract: A tour of some of the world’s exceptional places.
keywords: The Geography of Genius: A Search for the World's Most Creative Places From Ancient Athens to Silicon Valley (Book)

items.title: Brazil: Protest Over Higher Bus Fares Erupt in 3 Cities
items.abstract: Demonstrations in São Paulo, Rio de Janeiro and Belo Horizonte reflected resentment over efforts to cover budget shortfalls.

items.title: As Cuomo Acts on Homeless Problem, New York City Blames State Cuts
items.abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is only one player in addressing the issue in the city, but decisions his administration has made have left the city shouldering more of the burden.

items.title: Pritzker Prize for Architecture Is Awarded to Alejandro Aravena of Chile
items.abstract: Mr. Aravena, who has focused on low-cost social housing and reconstructing after natural disasters, received the honor as Chile emerges as a locus of noteworthy architecture.

items.title: In High-Tech Cities, No More Potholes, but What About Privacy?
items.abstract: Cities, including some far from the coasts, are vying to use technology to guide services. But the race toward “smart cities” is raising privacy worries.

items.title: How Cities Make Money by Fining the Poor
items.abstract: In many parts of America, like Corinth, Miss., judges are locking up defendants who can’t pay — sometimes for months at a time.

items.title: Washington’s Strong Economy, Financed by Taxpayers, Takes Hit From Shutdown
items.abstract: As the country nears the end of its third week of a government shutdown, the nation’s capital has borne the brunt of its consequences.

items.title: Mayor de Blasio Says Wealth Is ‘in the Wrong Hands,’ Pledges to Redistribute It
items.abstract: In his State of the City address, Mayor Bill de Blasio offered progressive promises and a new ferry between Staten Island and Manhattan’s West Side.

items.title: What if Cities Are No Longer the Land of Opportunity for Low-Skilled Workers?
items.abstract: Dense cities have long promised higher wages, but now that is primarily true for workers with more education, a new analysis finds.

items.title: Eric Adams Takes Office as New York City’s 110th Mayor at a Perilous Moment
items.abstract: Eric Adams, the city’s second Black mayor, faces difficult decisions over how to lead New York City through the next wave of the pandemic.

items.title: Nashville Finds Opportunity in the Hole a Bomber Left in the Heart of the City
items.abstract: Since the explosion last Christmas, the city has grappled with how rebuilding will fit into its larger ambitions of transforming downtown. The hope is to draw more than just tourists.

items.title: A New Mayor and a New Relationship Between City Hall and Albany
items.abstract: Unlike their feuding predecessors, Mayor Eric Adams and Gov. Kathy Hochul appear to be getting along. They have their reasons.

items.title: As Omicron Infects Workers, Subway Service Suffers
items.abstract: With coronavirus cases surging in New York, about 21 percent of subway operators and conductors were absent this week, causing suspensions on three lines and changed schedules on others.

items.title: An Alabama Town’s Sewage Woes Test Biden’s Infrastructure Ambitions
items.abstract: The new law allocates $11.7 billion for wastewater and stormwater projects. Will it get to the impoverished communities who need it most?
